articles.headline: How 4 Federal Lawyers Paved the Way to Kill Osama bin Laden
articles.snippet: The lawyers tried to prepare for any legal obstacles — and made it all but inevitable that Bin Laden would be killed, not captured.
articles.abstract: The lawyers tried to prepare for any legal obstacles — and made it all but inevitable that Bin Laden would be killed, not captured.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Weeks before President Obama ordered the raid on Osama bin Laden’s compound in May 2011, four administration lawyers developed rationales intended to overcome any legal obstacles — and made it all but inevitable that Navy SEALs would kill the fugitive Qaeda leader, not capture him.

articles.headline: Fed Keeps Interest Rates Near Zero, but Says Economic Indicators Remain Strong
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve’s statement, issued after a two-day meeting of its policy-making committee, left open the possibility of a rate increase in December.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve’s statement, issued after a two-day meeting of its policy-making committee, left open the possibility of a rate increase in December.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve wants to make sure that investors understand that it could raise its benchmark interest rate in December; it just is not ready to make any promises yet.

articles.headline: A Gas Discovery in Egypt Threatens to Upend Mideast Energy Diplomacy
articles.snippet: The Zohr field is already brightening Egypt’s economic prospects, but the discovery also has repercussions for relations with Arab neighbors and with Israel.
articles.abstract: The Zohr field is already brightening Egypt’s economic prospects, but the discovery also has repercussions for relations with Arab neighbors and with Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Italian energy company Eni knew it was taking a big risk this summer when it spent $60 million on an exploratory rig and began drilling more than 100 miles off the coast of Egypt.

articles.headline: For American-Israeli Teacher, Death Came on the No. 78 Bus
articles.snippet: A family bade farewell to Richard Lakin, who was shot and stabbed to death on a bus in Jerusalem at the height of this month’s violent uprising.
articles.abstract: A family bade farewell to Richard Lakin, who was shot and stabbed to death on a bus in Jerusalem at the height of this month’s violent uprising.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel — Richard Lakin’s funeral on Wednesday was touching in the tiny, usual ways. His grown son tearfully recalled a man who began every morning with a banana and a chuckle. His teenage granddaughter thanked him for teaching her to ride a bike and, barely able to get the words out, “for watching ‘Charlotte’s Web’ endless times with me.”

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank Is Expected to Settle Sanctions Violation Case for at Least $200 Million
articles.snippet: The banking giant, which has struggled since the financial crisis, is expected to announce soon it will pay at least $200 million to resolve investigations into dealings with blacklisted countries.
articles.abstract: The banking giant, which has struggled since the financial crisis, is expected to announce soon it will pay at least $200 million to resolve investigations into dealings with blacklisted countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank, the German financial giant with a big presence on Wall Street, is close to settling one of the many government investigations it currently faces.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Republican Candidates Take Sharp Tone in Third Debate
articles.snippet: In a change from previous debates, the candidates dove into the gritty details of economic plans and entitlement programs, but exchanges grew contentious and political friendships were strained.
articles.abstract: In a change from previous debates, the candidates dove into the gritty details of economic plans and entitlement programs, but exchanges grew contentious and political friendships were strained.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida coolly rebuffed attacks from his onetime mentor, Jeb Bush, and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas emerged as a champion of social conservatives at Wednesday’s Republican presidential debate, as both men found their voices after months of lower-key performances.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: States Struggle With What to Do With Sex Offenders After Prison
articles.snippet: A Minnesota program to treat dangerous sex offenders until it is safe for them to go home has held hundreds of people indefinitely over the past two decades.
articles.abstract: A Minnesota program to treat dangerous sex offenders until it is safe for them to go home has held hundreds of people indefinitely over the past two decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOOSE LAKE, Minn. — Behind razor wire and locked metal doors, hundreds of men waited on a recent morning to be counted, part of the daily routine inside a remote facility here that was built based on a design for a prison.

articles.headline: China Ends One-Child Policy, Allowing Families Two Children
articles.snippet: The decision ends decades of restrictive policies that limited most urban families to one child.
articles.abstract: The decision ends decades of restrictive policies that limited most urban families to one child.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Driven by fears that an aging population could jeopardize China’s economic ascent, the Communist Party leadership ended its decades-old “one child” policy on Thursday, announcing that all married couples would be allowed to have two children.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 1.5% Rate in Third Quarter
articles.snippet: The slower tempo of growth in July, August and September was expected but represents a marked drop from the 3.9 percent pace of expansion in the spring.
articles.abstract: The slower tempo of growth in July, August and September was expected but represents a marked drop from the 3.9 percent pace of expansion in the spring.

articles.headline: Pfizer Bid for Allergan Has Its Eyes on Ireland
articles.snippet: Pfizer, one of America’s oldest drug makers, is again looking to renounce its corporate citizenship by buying a foreign rival.
articles.abstract: Pfizer, one of America’s oldest drug makers, is again looking to renounce its corporate citizenship by buying a foreign rival.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer has long played an important role in United States history over its 166 years, including producing painkillers during the Civil War and penicillin in World War II.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: Past Partners, Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush Shift Directions
articles.snippet: After months of simmering tensions, the onetime political partners in Florida offered a preview of a fight that Mr. Bush and his allies see slipping from their grasp.
articles.abstract: After months of simmering tensions, the onetime political partners in Florida offered a preview of a fight that Mr. Bush and his allies see slipping from their grasp.
articles.lead_paragraph: Measured but optimistic, Senator Marco Rubio on Thursday stepped into the spotlight he always feared would come too early in the campaign and prepared for a bruising collision with Jeb Bush, his friend, neighbor and onetime political partner in Florida.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Maggie Haberman
